channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: Water Wars in India’s South
item.description: The two south Indian states of Kerala and Tamil Nadu are battling over a 112-year-old reservoir.
item.dc:creator: By SUHRITH PARTHASARATHY
item.media:credit: Courtesy of K K Najeeb/CSE Environment Photo Library
item.media:description: A view of the Mullaperiyar Dam in Idukki district of Kerala.

item.title: Accused War Criminal, 98, Dies Awaiting Trial
item.description: Laszlo Csatary had been accused of whipping and beating Jews and helping send them to the Auschwitz death camp in World War II.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Laszlo Csatary was charged in June with having “intentionally assisted the unlawful executions and tortures committed against Jewish people.”

item.title: Economic Expansion Slows Down in Japan
item.description: Economic growth in the second quarter fell short of the previous three months’ figure and of analysts’ expectations, possibly threatening plans for shrinking the nation’s soaring debt.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI

item.title: Israel Names Palestinian Prisoners to Be Released
item.description: The move to free 26 prisoners is part of a deal for the resumption of peace talks, set to begin Wednesday, but neither side seemed enthused about the announcement.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Hungarian Charged With Nazi-Era War Crimes Dies
item.description: Laszlo Csatary was a former police officer indicted in June by Hungarian authorities for abusing Jews and contributing to their deportation to Nazi death camps during World War II. He was 98.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Australian Prime Minister Accused of Breaking Debate Rules
item.description: Prime Minister Kevin Rudd has been criticized for his use of notecards in the first leadership debate of the federal election campaign.
item.dc:creator: By MATT SIEGEL

item.title: Gays in Russia Find No Haven, Despite Support From the West
item.description: Despite the breathtaking wealth and vibrant culture in its metropolises, Russia remains a country where discrimination and violence against gay people are widely tolerated.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Riot police officers guarded activists who had been beaten by antigay protesters at a rally in St. Petersburg, Russia, in June.

item.title: Tell Us About Your Experiences Being Gay in Russia / Быть геем в России: расскажите о вашем личном опыте
item.description: Recent legislation in Russia has spurred an international furor and a national debate on gays in society.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Rome Journal: Vibrant Market Is Heart of Multiethnic Capital
item.description: In a country still grappling with immigration, the food market in Piazza Vittorio Emanuele presents a different vision for Italy, one of an aging country’s future as a land of immigrants.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women from Guinea shopping for fish at the New Esquiline Market in Rome, which caters to immigrants from many places.

item.title: American Is Moved to North Korea Hospital
item.description: Kenneth Bae, 45, a tour operator who was sentenced to 15 years of hard labor, has left the camp where he was being held. His health has declined, his sister said.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ

item.title: Embassies Open, but Yemen Stays on Terror Watch
item.description: The American embassy in Yemen remained closed, underscoring the challenges President Obama faces in trying to reshape the nation’s counterterrorism strategy and fight an increasingly decentralized Al Qaeda.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Yemeni security forces and barriers blocked access to the United States Embassy in Sana on Sunday. The embassy remained closed even as other Middle East diplomatic outposts reopened.

item.title: Mosque Attack Causes Unease in Sri Lanka
item.description: A curfew was imposed in the capital and the United States expressed concern a day after a Buddhist-led mob vandalized a Muslim site.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE
item.media:description: Police officers outside a mosque vandalized by Buddhists in Colombo, Sri Lanka. A local curfew was imposed Sunday night.

item.title: Curfews Imposed in Indian-Held Kashmir
item.description: Indian forces and local authorities enforced the curfews after rioting on Friday left two civilians dead.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Soldiers on Sunday in Jammu, in the Indian-controlled portion of Kashmir, after rioting on Friday left two civilians dead. Strains between India and Pakistan have worsened recently.

item.title: Celebrity Weeklies Are Reveling in a Royal Baby, and Sales
item.description: After six months of so-so circulation numbers, the birth of Britain’s Prince George has resulted in record readership, in print and online.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUGHNEY
item.media:description: The Aug. 5 issue of People on Prince George’s birth was the magazine’s best-selling issue so far this year.

item.title: Police Put Off Dispersal of Pro-Morsi Sit-Ins
item.description: The Egyptian police appeared on Monday to have postponed once again their threat to begin choking off two Cairo sit-ins where tens of thousands have gathered to protest the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Muslim Brotherhood members and supporters of Mohamed Morsi, the ousted president, at a square in Cairo on Sunday.

item.title: Sanofi Being Investigated for Bribery by China
item.description: Health and disciplinary authorities are investigating claims published in a Chinese newspaper that Sanofi paid hundreds of doctors to prescribe its products.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: 5 Soldiers Killed in Southern Yemen
item.description: Gunmen suspected of being militants with Al Qaeda killed the Yemeni soldiers, an official said, as American Embassies across the Muslim and Arab world reopened after a terrorism threat.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: In Mali’s Election, Dashes of Optimism and Realism
item.description: Some citizens said the vote was proof that Mali, after 18 months of armed turmoil, was intent on righting itself and renewing a democratic tradition.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: In Bamako, Mali, poll workers counted the number of people who voted before counting their ballots in the presidential runoff election.

item.title: Path to United States Practice Is Long Slog to Foreign Doctors
item.description: Despite a shortage of doctors in some parts of the United States, a trend that may worsen under the new health care law, it takes years for a foreign doctor to be licensed here.
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.dc:creator: By CATHERINE RAMPELL
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sajith Abeyawickrama, who came in 2010 from Sri Lanka, teaches exam prep on genetics at Kaplan Medical in Newark, N.J.

item.title: New Israeli Housing Bids Raise Tensions Before Peace Talks
item.description: A plan to build houses in contested East Jerusalem and West Bank settlements intensifies the already charged atmosphere, three days before the resumption of Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Two Israelis who bought an apartment in the new housing project in East Jerusalem stood next to an advertisement on Sunday.

item.title: Leaker’s Father Says He Will Visit Son in Russia
item.description: Lon Snowden, Edward J. Snowden’s father, and the family’s lawyer indicated they would encourage a return to the United States, but only if acceptable trial conditions could be negotiated.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN KNOWLTON
item.media:description: Lon Snowden, the father of Edward J. Snowden, spoke during an interview in Washington on Wednesday.

item.title: Nokia Map Project Sheds Light on Belarus’s Roads
item.description: The former Soviet republic, a black holes for motorists where reliable map data are held by the authoritarian government, is undergoing a geographic coming out with volunteers’ help.
item.dc:creator: By KEVIN J. O’BRIEN

item.title: Letter From Washington: More Opportunities for the More Unpopular Party
item.description: Despite their falling standing with the public, Republicans seem certain to hold the U.S. House of Representatives and to pick up U.S. Senate seats in congressional elections next year.
item.dc:creator: By ALBERT R. HUNT | BLOOMBERG VIEW

item.title: Northern Ireland Police Vow to Pursue Militants
item.description: The police chief of Northern Ireland vowed to imprison Protestant militants after scores of them attacked and wounded 56 officers protecting a parade.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: A protester pushed a garbage bin that was set on fire on Friday during clashes with police in Belfast, Northern Ireland.

item.title: Car Bombings Kill Scores Across Iraq
item.description: As Iraqis on Saturday celebrated Id al-Fitr, the holiday that marks the end of Ramadan, a string of car bombs struck in mostly Shiite neighborhoods, killing more than 60 people, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Nine car bombs struck around Baghdad, the capital.
